reviewText:
Short version: A big surprise. If you like tower defense at all and don't mind FPS, give it a shot. A great blend of strategy + action.

Long version: Sanctum is great for TD fans that either like or don't mind some FPS action in their games. The two aspects blend together very well; on lower difficulties, one can pretty easily focus on one over the other and do fine, while on higher difficulties both are needed pretty equally. Additionally, there are towers that help your shots and a gun that helps your towers, ensuring that the two aren't just separate parts of the same game but actually integrated together.

Even aside from FPS tactics, there's a fair amount more strategy than in most TD games, as the player must build a map for the enemies to travel on and building good maps can be necessary for survival. Building a map that makes enemies take longer to travel necessarily means less space for defensive towers, balancing the game with a choice of longer path or more firepower. And of course, correct positioning of towers for the most effective use of each one is as important as always in a TD game. Even the size of certain towers can be a strategic point for ensuring the player can move around flexibly.

One can bring 3 different guns and up to 6 different towers to maps, ensuring many different ways to play the game, although the total number of guns and towers may be a bit low to take full advantage of that.

If there's one problem I have with the game it's that some of the map designs come off as very lazy, but you'll largely forget about that when constructing a maze. I haven't played much multiplayer or survival mode myself, but in later waves of longer games, guns can also come to be seemingly ineffectual, as damage doesn't scale at all with the growing power of enemies. Sanctum does what it does near perfectly and there are very few changes I would consider making to improve it.

reviewText:
Sanctum is a fun and challenging game. It requires you to balance resources and defense structures. The goal of each map is to defend a core from incoming waves of monsters. Simple right? It's not. Each wave is unique in that the content varies. Some waves may only contain one monster, while another wave can contain many types. Each monster has a specific weak spot that you target to kill them more effectively. You have to destoy these waves by constructing an efficient maze of towers and guns. But you don't have unlimited resources; only what is given to you after each wave. That's when creativity and balancing come into play.

The game is even more fun under mulitplayer mode. With more people, you have more resources to spend to defend your core. However, the monster waves are random and stronger than the single player version. Communication is key to having a sucessful game. A method that can be used have each person focus on a type of tower (one person can focus on anti-air and floors, while another one could focus on ground and laser towers)

This game was worth the purchase. It provides you with a great challenge. Be warned though because each round can take up to an hour or more. If you have plenty of time to kill and want a challenge, then this game is for you. But if you don't have the time or patience to play, skip this game. There will be times where after playing for 45 minutest to an hour, you find out that your core has been attacked and you no longer have that 100%. You quit and then you resume from last save. So have paitence when playing this game.

One last note: Play around with the multiplayer chat. You'll be laughing a lot.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this one quite a bit.  Many if not most games I've played that try to mix tower defense with a controllable character fall flat because the balance doesn't work.  In this one, though, you can't only focus on one aspect.  If you just level up your weapons a ton, you'll run up against cooldowns and ammo restrictions and never be able to gun down all the enemies yourself.  If you only build towers and try to take a smoke break during the level, you'll be overrun during waves that have skill-dependent enemies.
The inclusion of enemies with a weak point that the player can aim for, but the towers won't, is an inspired choice.  It forces you to build and act in concert with your defenses.  Tough enemies can be slowed down, things that are only vulnerable in a single spot can be sniped, and swarms can be intelligently targeted with AOE attacks.  The sole drawback is that you can only hold 3 guns, and the sniper rifle and cold gun seem, to me, indispensable.

The other complaint I can make is that the 3-D nature of the game isn't fully supported/exploited.  So, unlike most TD games, a tower can't just shoot anything in its 'range'.  It has to have line-of-sight (in most cases).  This is good, as it forces you to think about where to put your blocks, which ones to make shot-transparent, and what obstacles in the level will affect your fields of fire. It's bad, though, because the game will show you a circle on the overhead view that denotes the tower's max range, but nothing else.  If you want to learn what it can actually see, the only solutions are to put your character's perspective as close as you can to the tower's (usually impossible, since you can't stand inside it, and the towers are mostly a lot taller than your PC) or observe what it shoots at during the levels (which requires you to look carefully at the overview while the action's going on, and not participate in the defense).  A feature that gave you the POV of the tower would make this so much easier.
Of note, this recommendation includes the free add-ons unlocking new towers and weapons, as well as the paid-for DLC granting new maps.  This adds much-needed variety, and I would probably be less enthusiastic if I'd played it at release.

Let me start by saying that I do not recommend this game at its full price. I paid .99 USD for it so for that price you cant really go too wrong. I enjoyed the game at first, its uniqu(ish) blend of FPS and TD was amusing, but I soon started to see that the game was lacking in some areas. I played with a friend as well to see what how he felt about and found us agreeing in most areas. My biggest griped was polish. The game seems like it coulda used a decent amount it. I noticed animations gliching out a bunch of times, turrets having fits when enemies quickly moved in and out of range, the player often getting stuck and needing to teleport out (seems like a copout from a dev standpoint).

My friends biggest gripe was odd balancing. We often found that the first 4-6 waves of enemies we could stop before they barely made any progress out of the starting point, then the next wave would break right through to the end and we'd loose. Easy, easy, easy, easy, easy, insanely hard. Not a fun difficutly curve.

Also, while the fps portions of the game all worked nicely and looked good, the TD portions seemed ad hoc assembly of tower defense features that didnt fit together to well anf felt clunky. Like the game was designed as a FPS defense kinda thing, then someone added in the the tower stuff where ever it would fit. That being said if you love FPSs and are so so about TDs, then this might just be for you! But if you love TDs and could take or leave a FPS, then this isnt going to mesh well.

Its not a bad game, and Im sure there are lots of people who love it. But, it wanst my cup of tea. To me it felt like 2/10 TD and 8/10 FPS, where a smash hit in my eyes would have those numbers transposed. Over all i would give it a 6 out of 10. Not bad, but not good enough to keep me coming back for more.

reviewText:
Sanctum is a fun and challenging game. It requires you to balance resources and defense structures. The goal of each map is to defend a core from incoming waves of monsters. Simple right? It's not. Each wave is unique in that the content varies. Some waves may only contain one monster, while another wave can contain many types. Each monster has a specific weak spot that you target to kill them more effectively.  You have to destoy these waves by constructing an efficient maze of towers and guns. But you don't have unlimited resources; only what is given to you after each wave. That's when creativity and balancing come into play.

The game is even more fun under mulitplayer mode. With more people, you have more resources to spend to defend your core. However, the monster waves are random and stronger than the single player  version. Communication is key to having a sucessful game. A method that can be used have each person focus on a type of tower (one person can focus on anti-air and floors, while another one could focus on ground and laser towers)

This game was worth the purchase. It provides you with a great challenge. Be warned though because each round can take up to an hour or more. If you have plenty of time to kill and want a challenge, then this game is for you. But if you don't have the time or patience to play, skip this game. There will be times where after playing for 45 minutest to an hour, you find out that your core has been attacked and you no longer have that 100%. You quit and then you resume from last save. So have paitence when playing this game.

One last note: Play around with the multiplayer chat. You'll be laughing a lot.

reviewText:
I find Sanctum's first person tower defense (with heroes) style clunky, boring and overrated. The controls and user interface are the primary source of frustration. At no point do I feel in complete control of my game, unlike in better examples of this concept (Orcs Must Die).

The mix of genres presented here doesn't work for my tastes. Basically for Tower Defense I'd rather play a top-down game like Defense Grid, for a first-person shooter co-operative survival mode I'd rather play Left 4 Dead or TF2's MvM mode. For the genre-mix I'd much rather play the Orcs Must Die series. I cannot recommend Sanctum.

I would, however be curious to see how the concepts presented here have perhaps been polished in the sequel, Sanctum 2.

Possibly the only TD I'll ever play, and for one reason: this one makes you an integral part of the action.

Build your maze, build your turrets, co-ordinate with a buddy (or three), and blow up some alien critters. The upgrade system is intuitive and interesting as both your turrets and weapons can be upgraded, making both you and your maze a force to be reckoned with. Having a gun in your hand and seeing things in a first person perspective is really what sets this apart from the other TDs where you build your turrets and sit back, letting them do all the work. Depending on the enemy wave, you could sit back and watch your turrets annihilate the enemy, or you could build gigantic, winding maze and do all the dirty work yourself, but eventually it'll balance out to where both you and your turrets are splitting the damage fairly evenly and concentrating your upgrades on either weapons or turrets will lead to failure.

As an added bonus, the scenery is absolutely gorgeous in the surreal areas you'll be visiting; there is some astounding artistry put into this.

The environment can be a hazard to the player - fall off a ledge and enemies will push forward until you recover. This all allows for some varied and deep tactics. The number of maps, difficulty levels and achievements provides for many hours of replayability. The graphics and sound quality is good for an indie release, and the game is also very stable and bug free. The only major flaw is the lack of any kind of story to tie the levels together. But Sanctum is still great value for money, even at full price.

I have to say that this game took me by surprise. I picked it up on sale for less than a dollar. I wasn't expecting much. The screenshots and videos looked alright and the description sounded cool. Yet, I had been fooled by games like that before. I had never heard of the game before but decided to spend the extra change in my Steam Wallet on it, figuring I really wasn't losing out on anything. Am I glad I did!

First off, let me tell you I haven't played anything quite like this before. I have played FPS's and Tower Defence's, but never together. I enjoy both, but was wary of how they would mix. Needless to say I didn't come into it with high expectations, but I should have.

The graphics are decent/good, I like them, and for less than a dollar, they are great for sure. I also really like the art style as well as alien, turret, weapon, map, and character designs. It all seems really cool, especially since your weapons and turrets do change color and look when you upgrade them.

Maps have varied layouts, some with multiple paths to the end, some of which you can block off, and some with only one straight shot, and you have to maze your way from beginning to end. Some maps may have only one spawn for aliens, while another may have two or three. Another aspect I like is that you just don't build on the side of the path, you build on it, which allows you to create mazes, funnels, and plan out paths for the enemies. It also allows you to block of paths you don't want to deal with on multiple-path maps.

You have the ability to carry three different weapons and four turret desings into a match. All of these are upgradeable, which will lead to increased damage, range, fire-rate, piercing, etc. Your weapons do not have ammo, but can overheat, and upgrading them increases damage, range, and the amount of shots before overheat. One type of turret you can build is a mix of a teleporter and elevator. Basically it will lower itself, allowing you to get ontop of the turrets you build, allowing you to shoot down onto the aliens. YOu can also hit tab to go into overview mode, which shows the map, allowing you to teleport to these specific turrets.

Gameplay can get fast and frantic, especially if you get overrun by numbers or your design fails. Other times it can be a breeze, while you sit there taking pot-shots at oncoming aliens, while your turrets do most of the work. Each map you can play on three different difficulties, and there is also surival mode, which can really test your skills.

There is co-op multiplayer, I haven't tried it myself yet, but I plan too and it seems very fun.

All-in-all it is a very good game, a great mix of FPS and TD. A pleasant surprise for the cheap price I got it for, although I do believe it is worth full-price. There are map-pack dlc available, and I am looking forward to picking those up as well. Would recommend! 8.75/10

Ok, so I decided I would redo my Sanctum 1 review since I did terrible Sanctum 2, so I'll just explain why I prefer THIS one over the 2nd one.

PROS:

The game itself: I want to point this out to EVERYONE who apparently likes Sanctum 2 better, Sanctum 1 is a tower based game with FPS elements, so you can help your towers out as well as have something to do than just sit there.  The 2nd one is FPS based with towers involved and I HATE that, the best part about the first one was the huge maps, level up weapons, level up towers and killingfloors to high levels to do a s%#ton of damage with, teleport around the place getting in enemies faces, get infront of them to block them off so they couldn't get closer, etc. and that's why I loved it, the FPS part was just there for some entertainment and to help out friends/towers so you would have something to do

Large maps: A good chunk of the maps in this game are actually really big, seriously, some of the maps are ginormous and you have to be careful about where you put your towers, as well as where you should stand to help them out.

Weapons/Pick your own weapons: There are multiple weapons to pick from, i'm not going to list them all but i'll say my favorties are R.E.X., the Tesla Gun, and the Sniper, and leveling them up means more damage and more ammo, as well as quicker reload times.  And to top it all off you can pick your weapons instead of being forced 1 weapon, AND you also get 3 weapons instead of 2, making it more fun.

Level up weapons: This is another thing I adored about the first one, the level up system for weapons.  How this works is that you switch to your weapon inbetween rounds with SHIFT, and hold LMB (if you have enough money) And it upgrades it to the next level, the higher the level the more damage you do with it, there is a limit but it does a lot of damage.

NO. F%$KING. TOWER LIMIT: I hated this SO MUCH about the 2nd, there isn't a tower/block limit, there isn't, if you have the money and it isn't blocking the enemies path then you can put it there, and that's why I liked it, I hate how the 2nd one you have a limit, why a limit? That was one of the great things about the first one.

No stupid boss fights: There are no boss fights in this game, and that's another thing I like and don't like, I wish there was a big enemy to fight but in the 2nd one he's just a a$$hole.  Me and my friends spent 20 minutes in Sanctum 2 on the last wave and putting towers in places and making a longer maze for the boss, well apparently the boss gave us a middle finger and plowed through it all, making all of our time and money utterly useless, after we saw that we quit and played the first game again.

Towers:  Like I said in the first statement that this is a Tower based game with FPS elements, which means the towers do a good chunk of work and you are the support instead of it being vice versa.  There are multiple types of towers, my personal favorties are the killing floor which sits on the ground, and any enemy that runs over it takes damage, AND slows him down for a few seconds, and theres also this one with a long a$$ neck that pretty snipe enemies from across the map in a few hits.  There are others of course, try em out!

Teleport system: If you fall off the map or are wanting to go up to the front/back of the complex to get at enemies or just for the fun of it you can teleport around if you put down some teleport pads, makes it easy to swap around the map and help out friends or to get to enemies quickly instead of running there.

You can't die:  Yup, you aren't able to die at all and I like that a lot, it doesn't put a whole lot of tension or anything, if you fall off the map you just pick a place to teleport at with no worries.

Core: The Core is what you are trying to protect the aliens from, if too many get in it explodes and you lose, the bigger the enemy the more health it takes off, and you can't get any back, so keep those b@$#ards away from it at all costs.

No timer: I hated this about the 2nd as well, in the first inbetween rounds you get no timer, as much time as you need to set up your maze for enemies or put towers in places, get to certain high points for sniping, anything.  In the 2nd inbetween rounds half the time you get like 30 seconds to do whatever it is you have to before it starts and I hated that.

Enemy hits: If a enemy hits you you don't lose health or anything, he just knocks you back and shakes your camera around, making it a little woozy, then when your senses come back you can go after the guy that hit you.

CONS:

Teleport pads: At times when I was playing I would hug against a wall so I wouldn't get knocked back, but I ran back somehow cause a telepad came down to pick me up and I went back too far and into the hoard on the other side and I kind of got stuck.  I don't know if this is a nitpick or something that people hate cause my friends do it constantly as well and they get annoyed with it.

Towers: Some towers feel utterly useless, for instance there is a slow-pad for the floor like a Killing Floor is used, it slows the enemies down alot but doesn't do damage, when the Killing Floor does damage and slows them down abit.  And some are useful for only certain types, for instance gattling guns are for ground units only, and missile launchers for air targets only, some of them are mixed though, so they hit both air and ground units.

Longer waves mean harder enemies: When you upgrade all of your towers and weapons you would imagine you would be set, sadly that isn't true, as waves go on enemies get harder and harder with each wave, one time I had all of my towers (except 2-3) and all of my weapons upgraded and I was expecting to wipe the floor with everyone, but halfway through the wave the enemies were getting past my maze pretty quickly, and still had chunks of health left so I had to go back to the core and pick them off one by one, I lost sadly.  I would recommend you play with friends that way you can all gang up on the aliens.

WHAT I THINK:  I think this was the actual good game of the 2, even half of my friends who played the 1st and 2nd prefer the 1st one instead, I still play this game on occassion because it's still entertaining to me, and I love it for that, it has quite high replayability, and the text-to-voice chat system is just downright hilarious, I give this game a 8/10, it needs some fixing with some things but it's still very fun all around.  Worth it on a sale or as it sits!

Most of the monsters do not attack you, making it more like a target practice game.  Every enemy has a weak spot, which can make the sniper rifle a very fun weapon to utilize.
